ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD) Syndrome
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Supported by sound-induced dizziness (Tullio phenomenon), low-frequency conductive hearing loss with normal acoustic reflexes, abnormally low cVEMP thresholds, and CT confirmation of dehiscence.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Otosclerosis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered due to conductive hearing loss, but ruled out by the presence of acoustic reflexes and the specific vestibular symptoms (Tullio phenomenon).

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Perilymph Fistula
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Can present with pressure-induced dizziness, but imaging and VEMP results strongly favor SSCD.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing thresholds and identify any air-bone gaps.
To evaluate word recognition abilities and validate pure-tone thresholds.
To assess middle ear function and rule out common causes of conductive loss.
To check for retrocochlear pathology or middle ear fixation; presence in conductive loss suggests third window.
To evaluate functional balance and sensory integration.
To assess horizontal canal function and rule out other vestibular pathologies.
Diagnostic test for SSCD; assesses vestibular hypersensitivity/thresholds.
Imaging to visualize the bony dehiscence of the superior canal.
To quantify symptom severity and impact on quality of life.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiologic evaluation revealed a left-sided low-frequency conductive hearing loss. Crucially, tympanometry was normal and acoustic reflexes were present, a pattern highly suggestive of a third window lesion rather than middle ear pathology. Standard vestibular testing (CDP, VNG, Rotary Chair) was normal, indicating intact horizontal canal and general balance function despite the specific sound-induced symptoms.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal hearing right; mild conductive loss left at 250 and 500 Hz with air-bone gaps.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Excellent word recognition scores (100% Right, 96% Left).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Present at normal levels bilaterally, despite the conductive component on the left.

tests.name: Videonystagmography (VNG) & Rotary Chair
tests.result_summary: Normal oculomotor, caloric, and rotary chair findings; no nystagmus.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Specialized testing confirmed the diagnosis of SSCD. cVEMP thresholds were abnormally low in the affected left ear, indicating hypersensitivity. High-resolution CT imaging visualized the dehiscence. The subjective questionnaire documented severe symptoms, particularly dizziness triggered by loud noises and pressure.

tests.name: Cervical Vestibular-Evoked Myogenic Potential (cVEMP)
tests.result_summary: Normal thresholds Right (80-85 dB nHL); abnormally low thresholds Left (60-65 dB nHL).

tests.name: CT Scan (Temporal Bone)
tests.result_summary: Revealed thinning and/or dehiscence of the roof of the left superior semicircular canal.

tests.name: Subjective Questionnaire (SSCD Symptoms)
tests.result_summary: Pre-op scores showed profound symptoms (5/5) for dizziness, loud noise sensitivity, and pressure changes.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: At 3 weeks post-operatively, the patient completed a follow-up questionnaire. Results indicated partial improvement: pressure-induced vertigo had resolved, and general dizziness and loud-noise sensitivity were reduced. However, vertigo triggered by coughing, sneezing, or straining remained profound (5/5), and tinnitus severity was unchanged. The global severity of symptoms was rated as moderate.

tests.name: Subjective Questionnaire (SSCD Symptoms)
tests.result_summary: 3 weeks post-op scores: Dizziness 2/5 (Mild), Loud Noise Vertigo 1/5 (Slight), Pressure Vertigo 0/5 (None), Cough/Sneeze Vertigo 5/5 (Profound), Tinnitus 5/5 (Profound), Global Severity 3/5 (Moderate).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: At 11 weeks post-operatively, the patient reported significant overall improvement. Vertigo and imbalance were largely resolved, including triggers from pressure and coughing/sneezing. Slight sensitivity to loud noises persisted. Tinnitus remained profound, and some hearing trouble persisted, but aural fullness and autophony had resolved. The global impact on daily activities was reduced to slight.

tests.name: Subjective Questionnaire (SSCD Symptoms)
tests.result_summary: 11 weeks post-op scores: Dizziness 0/5 (None), Loud Noise Vertigo 1/5 (Slight), Pressure Vertigo 0/5 (None), Cough/Sneeze Vertigo 0/5 (None), Tinnitus 5/5 (Profound), Global Severity 1/5 (Slight).

proposed_items: Surgical repair of the superior semicircular canal dehiscence (cartilage cap technique via transmastoid approach)
Avoidance of triggers (loud sounds, pressure changes) if surgery is declined
counseling_actions: Explain the 'third window' phenomenon and how it allows pressure/sound to stimulate the balance system
Discuss the Tullio phenomenon (dizziness from loud sounds)
Explain the discrepancy between conductive hearing loss and normal tympanometry/reflexes
Discuss surgical risks (hearing loss, facial paralysis, dizziness) versus benefits

escalation.rationale_short: Referral for specialized testing (cVEMP, CT) and surgical evaluation of suspected SSCD.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor symptom resolution and quality of life using the subjective questionnaire.

expected_outcome: Subjective Questionnaire (SSCD Symptoms) at 11 weeks post-op: Significant improvement in dizziness and balance complaints; denied vertigo from pressure changes, coughing, or sneezing.
Subjective Questionnaire (SSCD Symptoms) at 11 weeks post-op: Reported only slight symptoms provoked by loud noises (score improved from 5 to 1).
Patient reported slight improvement in aural fullness and autophony, but denied reduction in tinnitus or hearing loss.
Overall global severity of ear symptoms reduced from profound (5/5) to slight (1/5) impact on daily activities.
